document.docAuthor: Chang, Zhi-Min, Yang, Lin & Chen, Xiang-Sheng
document.docTitle: Sivaloka trigona Chang & Chen 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: First records of the genera Sivaloka Distant, 1906, with two new species from China, and description of a new species of genus Kodaianella Fennah, 1956 (Hemiptera, Fulgoromorpha, Issidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First records of the genera Sivaloka Distant, 1906, with two new species from China, and description of a new species of genus Kodaianella Fennah, 1956 (Hemiptera, Fulgoromorpha, Issidae)

figureCitation.captionText: Figures 44 - 55. Sivaloka trigona Chang & Chen, sp. nov. 44 habitus, dorsal view 45 habitus, lateral view 46 head and thorax, dorsal view 47 head and thorax, lateral view 48 head, ventral view 49 forewing 50 male genitalia, lateral view 51 male anal segment, dorsal view 52 genital styles, lateral view 53 capitulum of genital styles, ventral view 54 phallobase and aedeagus, lateral view 55 phallobase and aedeagus, ventral view. Scale bars: 0.5 mm. Abbreviations: tp = triangular prominence; a = small spinous process; b = half-leaf process; c = lateral lobe; d = ventral lobe; e = hooked process.

subSubSection.paragraph: Holotype: ♂, China: Guangxi, Yangshuo County ( 24°59'N , 105°36'E ), 28 May 2009, W-B Zheng leg. (IEGU).
Body length (from apex of vertex to tip of forewings): male 5.00 mm; forewings: male 4.10 mm.

caption.paragraph:
Figures 44-55.
Sivaloka trigona
Chang & Chen, sp. nov. 44 habitus, dorsal view 45 habitus, lateral view 46 head and thorax, dorsal view 47 head and thorax, lateral view 48 head, ventral view 49 forewing 50 male genitalia, lateral view 51 male anal segment, dorsal view 52 genital styles, lateral view 53 capitulum of genital styles, ventral view 54 phallobase and aedeagus, lateral view 55 phallobase and aedeagus, ventral view. Scale bars: 0.5 mm. Abbreviations: tp = triangular prominence; a = small spinous process; b = half-leaf process; c = lateral lobe; d = ventral lobe; e = hooked process.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The specific name is derived from the Latin words "
trigona
" in reference to the triangular prominence near the middle of the dorsal margin of the genital styles.
